screens.title: Welcome to this FATCA, AEI, and QI eLearning
screens.text:
Credit Suisse applies the highest standards in adhering to regulatory requirements. In the context of the bank’s zero tolerance approach to tax evasion, it is critical that you are familiar with your responsibilities under the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA), the Automatic Exchange of Information (AEI), and the Qualified Intermediary regime (QI).

This course equips you to understand the general requirements of these regimes and your obligations as Credit Suisse personnel.

You must complete all five topics to finish the training.

texts.text:
An introduction to client tax reporting regimes and why they are relevant to Credit Suisse.

You must complete all topics to complete this training.

Links marked are not accessible from personal computers and mobile devices.

popups.title: Congratulations!
popups.content:
Following this training, you will need to complete your annual certification which requires you to certify that you have not provided any assistance to any client or account holder in the avoidance of FATCA and AEI and that you certify that you have no knowledge of a non-US account (FATCA) and/or a non-reportable account (AEI) held, or beneficially owned by, a specified US Person or a Reportable Person, respectively.

Finally, you are asked to certify that you have no knowledge of any FATCA/AEI indicia associated with an account that has not been recorded in the bank's systems.

The completion PDF can be used to show the training was completed.

You have now reached the end of this course. You may close your browser window or – if using the Saba Cloud app – select Done.

tiles.description: An introduction to client tax reporting regimes and why they are relevant to Credit Suisse.
A look at the documentation requirements that are in effect for FATCA, AEI, and QI and the "Reason to Know" principle.
A look at reporting, withholding and termination considerations.
A reminder of your key responsibilities.
A short assessment on some of the key areas of FATCA, AEI, and QI.

screens.text: Select to view the introductory learning nugget.

cues.text: You’ve probably heard of large corporations and individuals being involved in tax evasion, and of governments wanting to focus their attention on this problem.
And that’s exactly what they’re doing…
The tax reporting landscape is evolving under a number of regulatory regimes intended to provide greater transparency including:
the US Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act, that you will know as FATCA
the Automatic Exchange of Information, or AEI
and the Qualified Intermediary regime, also known as QI.
This training is designed to help you understand how these regimes impact your role, what your responsibilities are and what you need to do to make sure you comply with our policies.

screens.title: FATCA, AEI, and QI
screens.text:
Every day we work with clients and help them manage their assets.

Clients may locate their assets offshore for legitimate reasons, but some clients may take steps in an attempt to conceal their assets from tax authorities.

Governments have addressed this by working together to introduce measures that require the exchange of client information between tax authorities to combat tax evasion.

Essentially, these measures are the introduction of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA), Automatic Exchange of Information (AEI) and the evolution of the Qualified Intermediary regime (QI).

Select each of the tab headings to find out more.

tiles.title: FATCA
tiles.content: FATCA is a US tax law that essentially requires the identification, documentation and reporting of US clients with assets outside of the US to the US tax authorities.

tiles.title: AEI
tiles.content: The AEI regime has been adopted by countries outside of the US to do essentially the same thing as FATCA; that is, to require the identification, documentation and reporting of clients using offshore banking to their local tax authorities.

tiles.title: QI
tiles.content: The Qualified Intermediary regime requires the bank to identify and document clients invested in US securities so as to ensure the bank applies the correct taxation.

screens.title: FATCA, AEI, and QI key implications
screens.text:
FATCA, AEI, and QI share a common objective in improving global tax transparency. You’ll look at each of these in more detail later, however here are some of the main differences.

Select each of the headings to find out more.

slides.title: Identifying and documenting account holders
slides.text:
FATCA
The bank must identify and document US Persons who hold accounts outside the US
AEI
The bank must identify and document the tax residence/residencies of all clients
QI
The bank must identify and document all persons investing in US securities

slides.title: Reporting
slides.text:
FATCA accounts are reported to the US Internal Revenue Service directly or via local tax authorities
AEI accounts are reported to the tax authority where the client is resident via the local tax authorities
Income from QI accounts investing in US securities is reported directly to the US Internal Revenue Service

slides.title: Withholding tax
slides.text:
FATCA
30% withholding tax on income from US securities of relevant non-compliant account holders
AEI
No withholding tax obligation
QI
Income from US securities paid to non-US persons is subject to US withholding tax at a rate of 30%. A lower rate may apply under some conditions

popups.title: US Persons
popups.content: US citizens, US tax residents and entities organized in the US. In addition, certain entities with Controlling Persons who are US citizens or US tax residents.

screens.title: Why FATCA, AEI, and QI are important to me
screens.text:
I need to be able to answer questions about FATCA, AEI, and QI, so it’s especially important that I understand what implications they have for me, the bank and our clients.

It also means that I’m in a position to spot any potential tax documentation problems early on, and am able to escalate any breaches.

screens.title: Key messages
screens.text:
The bank has policies to meet FATCA, AEI, and QI requirements. These policies are key resources to maintaining transparency to global tax authorities.

So that you can play your part, you will need to understand the principles behind these tax requirements, and what you must do to follow the bank’s policies.

Use to continue to the next topic, or use to return to the Menu.
Select to view the introductory learning nugget.

cues.text: Picture this. You’re in a meeting with a client and you feel that the information they included in their initial documentation isn’t sufficient. Maybe you feel there’s something they’ve missed out, or something just doesn’t stack up.
Perhaps after onboarding a client you become aware of a change of information which affects the client’s tax status. What should you do?
This section is all about making sure the information a client provides matches up with what they tell you and what we know about them.
And how important it is to be aware that if a client’s situation changes, then the information we hold, and report, may also need to change.

screens.title: Individual Client: Characteristics and Documentation
screens.text:
All new accounts require FATCA and AEI documentation as a condition of account opening. Certain changes in account information that indicate the client may have become a US client (FATCA Indicia) or changed tax residence (AEI Indicia) may also trigger a requirement for the bank to collect new documentation.

Additionally, QI documentation is required when an individual wishes to invest in US securities.

Select each of the tab headings to find out more.

tiles.title: FATCA
tiles.content: FATCA is concerned with documenting if someone is a US person, that means, a US citizen or US resident, because they must pay US taxes regardless of where they live.

tiles.title: AEI
tiles.content: AEI is concerned with documenting tax residency(ies) of all clients.

tiles.title: QI
tiles.content:
QI documents whether someone is a US or non-US person.

The client may wish to claim a reduced tax rate on their income from US securities based on a tax treaty. In this case, QI documentation will confirm their country of tax residence.

screens.title: Entity Clients: Characteristics and Documentation requirements
screens.text:
Entity clients, like companies, partnerships and trusts, must provide FATCA and AEI documentation at account opening and upon a change in circumstances if the change affects their FATCA/AEI documentation.

To invest in US securities, QI documentation is also required.

The documentation usually has two steps: Select to learn more.

pages.title: Review where the client is tax resident
pages.text: Entities are required to tell us where they are tax resident. The bank then reviews the plausibility of what the client has told us against what we already know.

pages.title: Review the client’s FATCA/AEI classification
pages.text:
FATCA/AEI documentation requires entities to provide us with their FATCA/AEI classification. The bank then reviews the plausibility of the classification against what we already know.

In addition, some FATCA/AEI/QI classifications require us to look through the entity in order to further identify the US status and tax residencies of the entity’s Beneficial Owners or Controlling Persons.

popups.title: Controlling Persons
popups.content: The term “Controlling Persons” means the natural persons who exercise control over an entity. In the case of a trust, such term means the settlor, the trustees, the protector (if any), the beneficiaries or class of beneficiaries, and any other natural person exercising ultimate effective control over the trust. In the case of a legal arrangement other than a trust, such term means persons in equivalent or similar positions.

screens.title: Entity Clients: FATCA, AEI, and QI classifications
screens.text:
Classifications are important because they control who we report to tax authorities. These classifications are complex but can be divided into 3 main categories.

Select each of the headings to find out more.

slides.title: Financial Institution (FI)
slides.text: Financial Institutions are, like Credit Suisse, responsible for identifying, documenting and reporting their clients under FATCA/AEI. FIs include banks, insurance companies and most trust companies and funds.

slides.title: Active Non-financial Entity (ANFE)
slides.text: Active Non-financial Entities are primarily “active” operating companies, for example, a bakery, a car manufacturer or a furniture company.

slides.title: Passive Non-financial Entities (PNFE)
slides.text:
Passive Non-financial Entities are primarily private investment vehicles and domiciliary companies.

Passive Non-financial entities are special because banks must not only document the tax residence of the entity itself, but also look through and identify its Controlling Persons.

For reporting purposes, both the entity and the Controlling Persons may be reported.

If you aren’t certain if an entity client is a PNFE, or if you have Reason to Know that a PNFE has a Controlling Person that has not been identified, please escalate to your FATCA/AEI responsible contact. The FATCA, AEI, and QI intranet can tell you who is the right person to contact.

slides.title: QI classifications
slides.text: For QI, the same principles apply but the classification focuses on the structure of the company (e.g. corporation vs. partnership) rather than its function (e.g. Financial Institution or Active Non-financial Foreign Entity).

popups.title: Domiciliary companies
popups.content:
For FATCA purposes, the term “domiciliary companies” includes all legal entities, companies, establishments, foundations, trusts, fiduciary companies or similar associations, that are not operating. Indications that a company is a domiciliary company include:

  1. it has no business premises of its own (for example c/o address, registered office with a lawyer, fiduciary company, bank, etc.); or
  2. it has no employees of its own.

popups.title: Controlling Persons
popups.content: The term “Controlling Persons” means the natural persons who exercise control over an entity. In the case of a trust, such term means the settlor, the trustees, the protector (if any), the beneficiaries or class of beneficiaries, and any other natural person exercising ultimate effective control over the trust. In the case of a legal arrangement other than a trust, such term means persons in equivalent or similar positions.

screens.title: Reason to Know
screens.text:
FATCA, AEI, and QI require us to apply the “Reason to Know” principle every time we receive documentation for each account. We must review the documentation, and question the information the client has provided in the same way that a “reasonably prudent person” in our position would.

Applying Reason to Know is absolutely key to successfully fulfilling our obligations as a bank, and failure to do so could result in regulatory sanctions or fines for the bank and/or its personnel.

screens.title: Case Study: An RM meets a potential customer
screens.text:
Because Reason to Know is so important to FATCA, AEI, and QI, let’s explore what it looks like in real life.

Dmitri Prokofyic has completed his FATCA/AEI documentation in which he has told us he is a non-US person, tax resident in Cyprus.

He has a meeting with his RM, Sébastien. See if you can identify any discrepancies in Mr Prokofyic’s case.

parts.content:
Sébastien: Good afternoon Mr Prokofyic. Thank you for coming to see me again.

Dmitri: Not at all, and please call me Dmitri. Did you get all the documentation I sent?

Sébastien: Yes, I did.

Dmitri: Great, because you know I wanted to get this all sorted out so I can get home and spend some time with my children back in Paris.

Sébastien: I see. Just in case we need to get in touch. Your mailing address is the one here on this form, in Paris, right?

Dmitri: Of course. That is where I spend most of my time. You can send me any further documentation to that address.

Sébastien: Well, I think that’s everything. Thank you again for coming in and I hope you have a safe trip.

Dmitri: Thank you, I am looking forward to going home and seeing my family.

popups.content:
Mr Prokofyic stated that he is a non-US person, tax resident in Cyprus, but he said he was going home to France. He also gave me his mailing address, which is in Paris and said he spends most of his time there.

It looks like Mr Prokofyic may live in Paris and is resident there.

From our conversation, I am not sure if the information that Mr Prokofyic has given us on his documentation is plausible. This seems like an AEI question I should raise. I will consult the FATCA, AEI, and QI page to check who I should raise it with.

screens.text:
I noticed a few things that didn’t seem to add up. What about you?

Mr Prokofyic stated that he is a non-US person, tax resident in Cyprus, but he said he was going home to France. He also gave me his mailing address, which is in Paris and said he spends most of his time there.

It looks like Mr Prokofyic may live in Paris and is resident there.

From our conversation, I am not sure if the information that Mr Prokofyic has given us on his documentation is plausible. This seems like an AEI question I should raise. I will consult the FATCA, AEI, and QI page to check who I should raise it with.

screens.title: Key messages
screens.text:
All new accounts require FATCA/AEI documentation as a condition of account opening. QI documentation is required when a client wishes to invest in US securities.

There are two steps to documenting clients under the tax regimes. Clients must determine their:

  • tax residence and US status
  • additionally, for entities, their FATCA, AEI, and QI statuses.

There are three main categories of entity classification: Financial Institutions, Passive Non-financial Entities and Active Non-financial Entities.

Reason to Know obliges us to review the FATCA, AEI, and QI documentation and question the information in the same way a “reasonably prudent person” in the same position would.

Failure to apply Reason to Know properly may result in regulatory sanctions or fines for the bank and/or its personnel.

topics.title: How FATCA, AEI, and QI affect our clients

screens.text: Select to view the introductory learning nugget.

cues.text: Recording relevant client information and keeping it up-to-date is one thing.
Making sure the information is reported properly is another. For example,
Sara is an American citizen. So under FATCA, information about her Swiss account must be reported to the US tax authorities.
However, Norbert’s a UK tax resident. So under AEI, information about his Swiss account is reported to the Swiss tax authorities, and then on to the UK tax authorities.
In order to meet our regulatory obligations, we must make sure we provide the correct information to the relevant tax authorities.
And that’s what you’ll look at in this section.

screens.title: Reporting to Tax Authorities
screens.text: Colin is not sure about how FATCA, AEI, and QI reporting affect his clients, so he asks Bridgette for some clarification.

parts.content:
Colin: Hi Bridgette. I wonder if you can help me with a few questions about FATCA, AEI, and QI reporting.

Bridgette: Well, as you know, FATCA is focused on US persons. This means that “Reportable Clients” include those who have provided us with documentation of their US status.

Bridgette: It also includes Passive Non-financial entities where we must look-through and report the US Person Controlling Persons, and those clients we have requested documents from, but they haven’t returned them.

Bridgette: However, AEI focuses on clients who are tax resident in countries that have AEI agreements in place – we call these Reportable Jurisdictions. This means that clients who bank with us in a location that is different from their tax residency may be included in reporting to that location’s tax authority.

Bridgette: Also, the Controlling Persons of a Passive Non-financial Entity may be reported if they are tax resident outside the country where the bank is located. In this case, the location’s tax authority shares the information with the client’s local jurisdiction.

QI is slightly different because in general it only reports information about the income clients receive from US Securities.

Colin: Great. Can you give me an idea of what’s reported?

Bridgette: Yes, of course. For FATCA and AEI it’s very similar; the client’s name and tax number, account number, end of year account balance and income on the account.

But in a handful of jurisdictions, a portion of the FATCA reporting is on a pooled basis due to banking secrecy and data protection laws.

Bridgette: For QI, as I mentioned earlier, in nearly all cases the bank reports the income from US Securities directly to the US tax authorities on a pooled basis.

If you have more questions about Reporting, the FATCA, AEI, and QI intranet can tell you who the right person to ask is.

popups.title: US person
popups.content:
• A citizen (incl. multiple citizenship) or resident of the United States
  • A US domestic partnership
  • A US domestic corporation
  • Any estate (other than a non-US estate) – these are not reported
  • Any trust if a court within the United States is able to exercise primary supervision over the administration of the trust, and one or more US Persons have the authority to control all substantial decision of the trust.

popups.title: Reportable Jurisdiction
popups.content: The term “Reportable Jurisdiction” means a Jurisdiction with which an agreement is in place to exchange information.

popups.title: Pooled Reporting
popups.content: In Pooled Reporting, we do not report specific client information – instead we report total accounts and total assets.

pages.text:
Withholding Taxes are amounts taken from a client’s income before the income is paid to the client. The US imposes a 30% withholding tax on income from US securities paid to non-US persons.

Non-US clients are allowed to claim a reduced rate of withholding tax if their relevant tax jurisdiction has a tax treaty with the US. QI enables the collection of withholding tax on income from US securities and, where applicable, secures a reduced rate for clients.

Under FATCA, withholding acts as a penalty – it imposes a 30% withholding tax on income from US securities where clients do not provide documentation. Tax treaties don’t reduce FATCA withholding.

If FATCA withholding applies, it takes priority over QI withholding. Where FATCA withholding is not applied, US non-compliant account holders are subject to 24% "back-up" withholding under QI. Compliant US account holders are not subject to withholding tax on income from US securities.

screens.title: Termination
screens.text:
FATCA

For our private banking businesses, Credit Suisse terminates the relationships of clients who do not comply with our FATCA documentation requirements. This is governed by the FATCA Global Policy; Termination Rules

Client accounts that are subject to termination are transferred from RM ownership to the ownership of an independent team, who are responsible for executing the termination process.

AEI

As the AEI regime develops, certain governments are taking actions to issue rules or guidance that will require the closure of accounts that are not compliant. The bank closely monitors these developments and plans to implement processes where required.

The FATCA, AEI, and QI intranet can provide more information on these developments.

screens.title: No assistance in avoidance of FATCA, AEI, and QI
screens.text:
You need to be aware that certain actions, or intentional inactions, may result in assisting clients to avoid reporting and withholding.

Credit Suisse employees, including account holder onboarding teams and management personnel, are strictly prohibited from assisting, or knowingly permitting account holders, to avoid FATCA, AEI, and QI rules.

screens.title: Example Scenario 1
screens.text:
Alejandro, the RM, knows that his client is a US and Spanish dual citizen. His client has indicated that he does not want to deal with the hassle of a US status.

Should Alejandro only enter the Spanish citizenship in the system?

screens.title: Example Scenario 2
screens.text:
Rukshahna’s client tells her that he has set up a series of companies in order to separate out his assets, and lower the values reported to tax authorities under AEI. He wants to open an account for one of these companies with Credit Suisse.

Is it all right for Rukshahna to help him open the account?

screens.title: Example Scenario 3
screens.text:
Elizabeth’s client runs a toy factory. He is retiring and comes to see Elizabeth to tell her the news, and to expect a large payment sum into the account because he has sold the factory. He will only use the account going forward for personal investments and enjoying his retirement.

Should Elizabeth ignore the fact that her client mentioned the sale so that he doesn’t have to supply new FATCA/AEI documentation with the updated classification?

screens.title: Key messages
screens.text:
Credit Suisse is required to report, and in some circumstances withhold on, our clients’ accounts based on their tax residencies or US indicia.

In addition, private banking clients may be subject to termination where they are not compliant with FATCA documentation requirements.

It is important that Credit Suisse personnel follow all guidance and established procedures to ensure that the bank can correctly discharge its FATCA, AEI, and QI obligations. Failure to do so could result in regulatory action, financial penalties and the associated reputational damage to Credit Suisse.

Use to continue to the next topic, or use to return to the Menu.
Select to view the introductory learning nugget.

cues.text: It’s fairly obvious that it would be illegal to blatantly help a client evade tax.
But it’s just as wrong to turn a blind eye to a client’s attempts to evade tax themselves, or to help them in any way, or to fail to escalate a suspicion.
It’s your responsibility to make sure you follow FATCA, AEI and the QI requirements…
…that you can explain them and to shine a light on any suspicions by escalating breaches, or suspected breaches, immediately.

screens.title: Key messages
screens.text:
In summary, you should be applying the following concepts in your day-to-day work.

  • Do not aid clients in the avoidance of FATCA, AEI, and QI requirements
  • Know and understand your obligations under the Global Policies
  • Escalate any suspected breaches of policy to FATCA/AEI Compliance

questions.question:
Which of these regimes requires the bank to identify and document clients who wish to invest in US securities?

Select the correct option, and then Submit.
questions.feedback: The Qualified Intermediary regime requires the bank to identify and document clients who wish to invest in US securities to ensure the bank applies the correct withholding tax rate. FATCA requires the bank to identify and document the US status of all account holders regardless of whether they invest in US securities. AEI requires the bank to identify and document all clients' tax residency(ies) regardless of whether they invest in US securities.

Every time the client meets with an RM
